EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This material supersedes IRM 4.24.16 dated 12/20/2016. This IRM incorporates procedural guidance found in the interim guidance memorandum: SBSE-04-0617-0041, Statute Date for Fuel Inspection Related Penalties, dated June 22, 2017.
AUDIENCE

This section provides direction to SBSE Excise Fuel Territory Managers, Supervisory Fuel Compliance Officers, Fuel Group Managers, Fuel Compliance Officers, and Fuel Compliance Agents. Information in this section may also support coordination with SBSE excise groups.
Report Writing, Case Processing and

) The Fuel Compliance Program enforces the laws and regulations pertaining the following: a. Proper sale and use of dyed fuel b. Sulfur content of taxed, undyed diesel fuel c. Requirement to dye fuel by means of a mechanical dye injection d. Reporting requirements for the bulk distribution of fuel through pipeline barge e. Reporting requirements for the distribution of fuel below the terminal (

) Employees conduct fuel inspections throughout the fuel distribution system without prior notice to the taxpayer. The employee starts the work day from or her residence or Post of Duty (POD) station and travels to a site to an inspection. During the course of an inspection, interviews and tours are conducted, records are reviewed, and fuel samples are obtained. The are obtained from fuel storage tanks and the propulsion tanks of highway vehicles. The fuel samples are shipped to and tested by the Paciﬁc National Laboratory (PNNL), under an interagency agreement with the IRS. (

) Purpose - It is essential for senior-level officials, managers, and employees understand the procedures contained in this IRM section. This IRM contains procedural guidance pertaining to report writing, case processing and case routing procedures. (

) Audience - The intended audience of this IRM includes the Chief, Estate & Gift/Excise Tax Examination, Territory Managers, Group Managers, Fuel pliance Officers (FCOs) and Fuel Compliance Agents (FCAs). (
) Policy owner – Director, Specialty Examination Policy owns the policies contained herein. (
) Program owner – Program Manager, Excise Tax Policy is responsible for administration, procedures, and updates related to the fuel compliance program. (

) Primary stakeholders - Other areas that are affected by these policies and procedures include Centralized Case Processing (CCP), Technical Services, Appeals, Cincinnati Compliance Service Center (CCSC) and Workload Selection and Delivery (WSD). (
) The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of
became effective on
The federal excise tax imposed by IRC Section
no longer applied to removals of diesel fuel that are indelibly dyed (or dyed and in accordance with IRS regulations. The Fuel Compliance Program rolled in June of

Its primary goal was to ensure that all dyed fuel leaving the terminal rack was dyed within the prescribed concentration levels, as well as ensuring that dyed fuel was not being utilized in diesel powered vehicles tered or required to be registered by the State.

The Fuel Compliance Program enforces the laws and regulations pertaining to the following:
Program owner – Program Manager, Excise Tax Policy is responsible for the administration, procedures, and updates related to the fuel compliance
The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of
became effective on January
The federal excise tax imposed by IRC Section
no longer applied to removals of diesel fuel that are indelibly dyed (or dyed and marked) in accordance with IRS regulations. The Fuel Compliance Program rolled out in June of

Its primary goal was to ensure that all dyed fuel leaving the terminal rack was dyed within the prescribed concentration levels, as well as ensuring that dyed fuel was not being utilized in diesel powered vehicles
) IRC
(d) and Treas. Reg. §

(a) authorize officials the Internal Revenue Service, upon presenting appropriate credentials and written notice to the owner, operator, or agent in charge, to enter any place and to conduct inspections in accordance with paragraphs (a) through (c) Treas. Reg. §

IRS officials are authorized to inspect, examine, and/or search: • Equipment used or capable of being used for the production, transportation of fuel, fuel dyes, or fuel markers • Equipment used to determine the amount or composition of taxable • Equipment used for the dyeing or marking of fuel • Containers used or capable of being used for the production, transportation of fuel, fuel dyes, or fuel markers • Books and records kept to determine excise tax liability under IRC • Propulsion tanks of vehicles and trains • Fuel cargo storage tanks of vehicles, trains and marine vessels (
) Employees are authorized to take and remove samples in quantities that reasonably necessary to determine the composition of the fuel. See Treas. Reg. §
) Director, Specialty Examination Policy is responsible for the procedures policies in this IRM. (
) Program Manager, Excise Tax Policy is responsible for ensuring that the dures are accurate and updated regularly, as needed. (
) Chief, Estate & Gift/Excise Tax Examination is responsible for ensuring the procedures within this IRM are adhered to. (
) Territory Managers, Excise Tax Examination are responsible for ensuring the group managers are aware and adhere to the procedures in this IRM. (
) Group Managers, Excise Tax Examination are responsible for ensuring employees adhere to the procedures in this IRM. (

) There are Fuel Compliance Officer (FCO) groups and Fuel Compliance (FCA) groups. FCOs and FCAs are responsible for following all procedures this IRM. The term “employees” is used throughout this section and refers both the FCO and FCA positions. (
) Program Goals - The goal of this IRM is to provide guidance pertaining to report writing, case processing and Appeals procedures. and (

) Program Reports - The effectiveness of employees following the outlined in this IRM is evaluated with the use of the following tools: • Issue Management System (IMS) reports • Fiscal year plan monitoring reports • Examination Returns Control System (ERCS) reports • IMS Team Website (

) Program Effectiveness - The effectiveness of this program is not by revenue assessed or collected, but by revenue protected. IRS being vigilant and visible in all geographic regions, promotes voluntary taxpayer compliance. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
R
IRC
(d) and Treas. Reg. §

(a) authorize officials (employees) of the Internal Revenue Service, upon presenting appropriate credentials and a written notice to the owner, operator, or agent in charge, to enter any place and to conduct inspections in accordance with paragraphs (a) through (c) of Treas. Reg. §
IRS officials are authorized to inspect, examine, and/or search:

Equipment used or capable of being used for the production, storage, transportation of fuel, fuel dyes, or fuel markers Equipment used to determine the amount or composition of taxable fuel Equipment used for the dyeing or marking of fuel Containers used or capable of being used for the production, storage or transportation of fuel, fuel dyes, or fuel markers Books and records kept to determine excise tax liability under IRC Propulsion tanks of vehicles and trains Fuel cargo storage tanks of vehicles, trains and marine vessels

tional reviews Territory Managers conduct group operational reviews

) If the employee does not receive sample results within
business days after shipment, the employee should inform their group manager, who may inquire about the status of the sample. (
) Employees are responsible for building the hard copy penalty case ﬁles. (
) Employees will forward the hard copy penalty case ﬁle along with a referral Form
, Examination Information Report, to their group manager. See IRM
, Referrals. (

) If the taxpayer has a representative and has a valid power of attorney ing receipt of correspondence, then the employee must send all correspondence to both the taxpayer and the representative. See IRM Power of Attorney Rights and Responsibilities. (

) A state penalty does not automatically result in a federal penalty assessment. Information received from a state is considered along with all the other facts and circumstances. Each case is evaluated to determine if a federal penalty is warranted. In particular, the employee must carefully consider factors that affect the validity of the sample (i.e., contamination of the sample) and the tection of the taxpayer’s rights. Employees may need to contact the taxpayer and obtain additional samples to determine if a federal penalty is warranted. (

) All state penalty cases must be input into IMS. a. Employees who receive samples from state officers must document receipt of the samples and upload the state narratives in IMS. may only accept fuel samples from states with whom the IRS has entered a fuel sampling, information-sharing agreement. b. Tracking Code
State Fuel Usage Sample Penalties must be used for all state-initiated cases input into IMS. Tracking Code
super- sedes use of the other tracking codes listed in the tracking code table in IRM

, Penalty Case Processing Procedures. c. If the employee pursues a penalty for a federal violation, processing the federal case should not be delayed pending the outcome of the state case nor for any appeals related to that state case. The federal penalty case should be fully developed and stand on its own merits. d. If the employee does not pursue a penalty for a federal violation, the employee must input the explanation in IMS, but will treat the inspection as a no adverse action case. Employees must follow the procedures for closing the case as a no adverse action case. (

) The employee must conduct a follow-up inspection within

days of the issuance of the penalty package to verify whether the taxpayer is with the law, in particular, that the violations previously cited are not The follow-up inspection is a separate inspection and the employee should create a separate case ﬁle in IMS for each inspection. (
) Employees must follow the procedures outlined in this section for all inspection case ﬁles. Assembly for (
) Proper assembly of a case ﬁle minimizes delays, administrative problems, Inspection procedural errors. (
) Each penalty case ﬁle is placed in a separate folder. (
) All related cases are submitted together with the controlling case on top. for ﬁles must be bound securely together with a rubber band or strap to Case Files they are not separated in error. (
) If more than one folder is submitted, the folders should be numbered (i.e., Folder
of
, Folder
of
, etc), to easily identify if a portion of missing. (
